As you mentioned, Mr. Chairman, before I joined Google I was a federal prosecutor. As an assistant United States attorney, I prosecuted cyber crime; I brought some of the first cases against criminal copyright enforcement in the country. I recognize the challenges and the difficulties of protecting intellectual property online.

The legal issues that we'll discuss today are complex and challenging. They require thoughtful approaches to preserve and enhance the benefits of the Internet for consumers and businesses in America and the world. And Google is dedicated to addressing issues of online copyright infringement and counterfeiting.

We know that the future growth and the success of our industry relies on fighting the bad guys who break the law. And we stand ready to support further enforcement measures against rogue foreign websites, focusing on financial transactions and advertising where those measures are appropriate and narrowly targeted against the worst of the worst foreign websites, in line with Mr. Abrams' comments this morning.

We do have concerns, however, about extending new law to dictate natural search results. We'd like to work together to ensure that these efforts are effective, while not harming legitimate services and technologies that drive U.S. economic growth and our country's leadership in the global information economy.

Let me share several ways that Google combats copyright infringement and counterfeiting, and then discuss principles for how to address rogue foreign websites.

At YouTube, as Mr. Chairman, you recognized, we designed a powerful tool that rightsholders use to block or monetize infringing content. Our content I.D. system, developed using 50,000 engineering hours at a cost of over $30 million, scans every video uploaded to YouTube and typically within seconds compares it against more than 4 million reference files provided by rightsholders.

Today over a thousand media companies, including every major U.S. studio and record label, use content I.D., and most of them choose to monetize, rather than to block the content. This shows the win-win possibilities that Internet technologies can bring, getting money to rightsholders and innovative services to users.

When it comes to online services like our search engine, a major part of the explosive growth of the Internet in the United States and around the world is due to the strong legal foundation created by Congress in the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

Last year Google processed over 3 million DMCA takedowns across our products, including search. These came from copyright owners of all sorts -- big movie studios to small publishers of needlepoint patterns.

And currently Google engineers are building new tools so we can act in reliable copyright takedown requests on our search engine within 24 hours. We're already testing the new tool with a content industry partner and we hope to invite other partners into that test in the weeks ahead.

When copyright owners tell us about infringements, we disable access to the infringing content, whether that content comes from foreign or domestic sources. The shared responsibility of the DMCA works. It assures that online platforms like Google or Facebook or Twitter will not face crippling liability when users post comments or files to online sites.

And as we committed last year, we're already excluding several piracy-related terms from appearing in autocomplete, a feature on Google that predicts queries as users type, and we've asked content industry representatives to provide other terms for consideration.

Turning to our advertising programs, in AdSense we prohibit ads on infringing web pages and we use automated and manual review to weed out abuse. Last year alone we took action on our own initiative against over 12,000 sites for violating that policy.

To address counterfeiting, our policies ban selling ads to advertisers who market counterfeit goods, and they always have. We use automated tools to prevent violations of our policies and last year alone we invested over $60 million in these efforts. After all, a Google user who's duped by a fake good is less likely to click on another Google ad. For the integrity of the sponsored links on our site is of paramount importance to us.

In the last six months of 2010 alone we shut down 50,000 accounts for attempting to advertise counterfeit goods. And 95 percent of those shutdowns came not as a result of a complaint, but as a result of our own efforts. And while it sounds like a lot, and it is, the legitimate -- complaints we received concern less than one-quarter of 1 percent of advertisers.

We've also committed to an average response time of 24 hours to handle counterfeit complaints involving sponsored links, and that too is in process and should be rolling out fairly soon.

So finally, as you address the challenge of rogue foreign sites, I would ask that you keep in mind the following three points: First, aim squarely at the worst of the worst foreign websites without hurting legitimate technologies and businesses. We agree with the goal of going after websites that are outside the reach of U.S. law and whose main purpose is commercial infringement.

Procedural safeguards are critical, though, to ensure due process and to avoid mistakes costing legitimate businesses the use of their domain name.

Second, don't re-write the DMCA, an existing law that works. Businesses benefit from stable and predictable rules with clear standards. Targeted legislation to address rogue foreign websites must not inadvertently dismantle the legal framework that America's technology companies and innovators rely upon.

The DMCA strikes the right balance between thwarting infringement and preserving free speech, and we should build upon it, not undermine it.

Third and last, tailor intermediary obligations appropriately. Let me repeat: Google is open to working with the subcommittee on additional enforcement tools. Search engines already remove infringement by domestic and foreign sources, so we think it's right for additional measures to focus on financial transaction providers and advertising services, both of which Google provides. But any legislation should avoid a private right of action that would invite shakedowns against companies making good-faith efforts to comply with the law.

To sum up, these are complex issues. We need to address the enforcement problems while protecting the overwhelmingly positive benefits of the Internet for our country and the world. And we look forward to working with each of you to do just that.

Thank you very much.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you, Mr. Walker.

Ms. Jones, we're pleased to have your testimony.

MS. JONES: Good morning, Chairman Goodlatte. Thanks so much for the opportunity to be heard today.

You know, we put a of time and energy into getting rid of bad actors from the Internet at Go Daddy, so we sincerely appreciate that you guys have made parasites a priority for the subcommittee this Congress.

And I also want to extend my personal thanks to Ranking Member Watt and Chairman Smith and Ranking member Conyers of the full committee as well and, frankly, all the members of the subcommittee, because I spend a lot of my personal time on these issues, not because I have to, but because I think it's the right thing to do. And let me tell you, it's nice to know that I have an ally in this fight, because sometimes we feel like we're out there all by ourselves.

Having worked closely with law enforcement, the intellectual property community and others on a wide variety of issues related to parasites, it is clear to me that we still have a long way to go.

I'll be the first to admit that there is no silver bullet. No silver bullet; it doesn't exist. Just like in offline crimes, it appears there will always be bad guys on the Internet; that is a stark reality we all must face. And although some of us have done a lot, there is still a lot more that some can do. So let's talk about what that looks like.

We have had great success in the past with a hybrid approach to illegal content. That means voluntary industry cooperation on the one hand, among all of the industry players, accompanied by targeted, specific federal legislation designed to protect the companies that are doing the right thing, but provide a consequence for those who do not. We've used this approach in addressing child pornography, for example, to great effect.

And Go Daddy and Google recently worked together with the White House Intellectual Property Enforcement Coordinator to gather representatives from all of the major industry players to address rogue online pharmacies. We feel like we're making progress there as well.

That effort resulted in the formation of a group known as the Center for Safe Internet Pharmacies. That group's mission is to share information among all of the players, work together to terminate services for illegal online drug sellers. Whatever your service is -- if you're a payment card provider, if you're a paid advertising provider, if you're a domain name registrar, whatever it is, turn off your services. We feel like that hybrid approach there is going to make it possible for us to address a significant number of illegal drug sellers who operate online today.

So we support that type of hybrid approach to address a variety of types of criminal activity, such as child abuse, rogue pharmacies, spam, phishing, identity theft, intellectual property infringement, terrorism, hate speech, on and on and on. We think it works in all of those situations.

Of course, it's always just as important to focus on enforcement as it is to enact new legislation. To do that, we would suggest a few simple things. I think Ranking Member Conyers mentioned this in his statement; that is, follow the money. Shut down all of the choke points in the system, because we have to disincentive the bad actors. So in the IP context, for example, we would take away the ability to search for, pay for, ship and make money from selling stolen or counterfeit goods.

But we have to do that while encouraging new innovation and research and development. One thing we know is that the better we get, the better we get. That means we have to think of things we can hardly even imagine right now.

So what happens, for instance, in the case of cyber lockers or infringing mobile applications or whatever infringement is going to come up that's invented in the future? If we establish a set of rules and procedures such as the DMCA which can be applied to a wide array of situations, we can possibly address those things that aren't, as if they were. None of us can predict the next big thing. I mean, who knows what's the next eBay or AOL or Netscape or Go Daddy or Google or Twitter? Who knows?

Not so long ago there was a monopoly for selling domain names. Nobody had ever heard of an Internet browser or even a search engine. The term "social media" didn't exist; it's common understanding now. And not too long from now there's going to be another idea like that that nobody's ever heard of. We have to think in terms of concepts rather than URLs or domain names or IP addresses or whatever to make legislation that's designed to outlast the current ideas. And because these issues reach outside our borders, we should all take steps to bind our foreign affiliates to the actions that we take here in the United States.

A huge number of our customers make a living operating online businesses. That's how they make their money. And their ability to continue to do so is very important to us. We would challenge our counterparts in the Internet ecosystem to do what we do at Go Daddy; that is, to voluntarily take action against the people that we know to be using our system for illicit purposes, and that includes registrars, registries, hosting providers, payment processors, shippers, ISPs, search engines, online advertising providers and oh, by the way, whoever joins the community next, whoever that is, we challenge them all to make the same commitment.

And I would submit that unless and until we provide a consequence for the businesses that facilitate criminals in their systems, there will always be a safe harbor, a place where crooks can go to engage in crimes online, and we must fix that hole in the fence.

Thank you very much for the time.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you, Ms. Jones.

And I'll recognize myself to begin the questioning. And let me warn my committee members, I may take a little extra time here because I want to go into some detail with this issue, with some specific examples.

And let me say at the outset that I want to restate my belief that tech and content, two areas in which this committee has great interest, are not enemies and that they both bring innovation to the table to solve various problems and they need each other and we need both of them contributing to solve this problem.

And Mr. Walker, let me just say I'm a -- I'm an avid user of Google's search engine and I welcome your comments here today that you want to work with the committee on some legislative solutions that might involve your company and other -- other players in the tech community in this. And we -- and we hear your concerns as well.

And I want to commend you for a news release which I'll put in the record that says, "Google Boots Grooveshark from Android Market," and noted that this was done yesterday. Grooveshark is a music app that has been found by many of the top music labels to be violating copyright law, and a Google spokesman said, "We remove apps from the Android market that violate our terms of service," and it was also noted that we were having a hearing on the subject here today. But we commend you for that.

I want to go into some details about some of the things we found in recent searches, however. In preparation for today's hearing we conducted searches in Google for "free MP3 Taylor Swift," quote- unquote.

Over the past several days, the first page of each search return appeared to show all unlicensed sites. We checked with the distributor of Taylor Swift's recordings and they provided us three screen shots from yesterday that show only two authorized sites out of nearly 30. To access the first of those, a consumer would have to scroll past the first 14 suggested by Google.

You wrote recently that Google was, quote, "a big fan of making authorized content more accessible," end quote, four months ago, and yet this is the result. I intend to check in a week, in a month, in three months and six months. When I do that, will I find this same problem in existence? What is Google doing about this?

MR. WALKER: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Let me go to the Grooveshark example first. I want to flag that is not the first time we've removed items from that app store. We removed almost 2,000 different applications from the app store over time -- (word inaudible) -- 2 (hundred) or 300 in February alone.

So we continue to look not just for copyright infringement, but now we're in many other things. There is -- you can recognize, I believe, about 200,000 different applications, so it's a major challenge for us to go through all those, but we are -- (inaudible).

(Cross talk.)

REP. GOODLATTE: And we commend you for that.

MR. WALKER: With regard to the additional items in the search results, we do try and remove -- when we get notice of these individual infringing items, obviously we try and take them down. At the same time, we have said we're eager to work with the content industry on ways of making their sites more accessible.

In some cases when they offer preview content or other kinds of things where you can listen to 30 seconds or a minute or a trial copy of a song, for example, that's very attractive to users. And we talk with them about ways of partnering that would actually make that more visible within the snippets, within the search results returned. And so as you get users clicking on that, that's sort of a natural signal. The cream rises to the top, even as we try and pull the bad guys out.

Now, that said, the Internet's a big place. And as I think all the witnesses have said, we're never going to get rid of all the bad guys. We play the whack-a-mole problem as much as the content industry does, and it frustrates us. And when you hear me talk about taking down 50,000 sites for this or 12,000 accounts for that, that's cost us a lot of time and effort. It drives us crazy trying to get rid of these guys because, of course, we take them down in one place, they come back up in another place using a different credit card, using a different IP address. So it is a constant battle.

We think the best way to fight that battle is collaboratively. To your point about the content industry and the technology industry working together, we're in the best position to rapidly remove content and build tools and filters to help do that.

The content industry is in the best position, maybe unique position, to let us know what's authorized and what's not. Because, of course, there are multiple authorized sites for different kinds of songs. The music industry is a very complicated place with label rights and publisher rights that expire over times and different geographies and the like.

They know what's authorized and what's not, and we rely on them to let us know, and then we take action.

REP. GOODLATTE: Let me -- let me follow up on that. I have indicated I use Google frequently. I'm frequently amazed at the sophistication of the algorithms that you use in your -- in your search process. And I often, when I type in things I like to see, you know, how many letters I have to type in before Google knows what I'm looking for. And I'm -- am frequently very impressed.

Three days ago we conducted a search for "watch movies online." We typed in those words. Without prompting, the first suggestion that appeared in the drop-down box that comes --which is exactly what I'm talking about, anticipating what I want -- in the drop-down box the first suggestion was "watch free bootleg movies online." And I'm sure, as a former federal prosecutor, you know the meaning of the term "bootleg."

If you click, you go to a results page full of infringing links. Clicking on one of the sites at the top of the page takes you to a website that is a notorious infringing site. It even advertises "pre- release movies." We have a movie coming out on Friday that they're advertising now will be available online illegally, that's going to appear -- "Hanna" is the movie, and it's going to appear in the theaters on Friday and you'll be able to see it online on Friday too, apparently. It even advertises pre-release movies.

Why exactly does Google suggest to users that they click on "watch free bootleg movies online"?

MR. WALKER: So the functionality you're speaking to is referred to as autocomplete. It's essentially the sum of what other users are doing. And so it's not really Google knowing what you want; it's you asking for things that other users are interested in.

And the fact that some of these terms come actually reinforces the importance of education among the American public. Because it's a reflection of how many users are in fact trying to seek illegal bootlegs, pirated, otherwise infringing content out there. Now --

REP. GOODLATTE: Well, let me ask you this. Would Google think it appropriate to -- when these things are called to your attention, review your -- the things that you anticipate and put up there and block some of them from occurring?

MR. WALKER: Absolutely. In fact, we've committed to do just that. And the challenge in doing it, obviously, is making sure that the terms we're blocking are uniquely -- or highly correlated with infringing material and not with -- with other sort of material.

So, for example, if you put in "cheap" or "free," many of those are perfectly appropriate and legitimate searches. You wouldn't want to not suggest that. Even terms like, you know, "faux" or "replica" in many cases it's faux leather or faux -- or even, you know, to go farther, terms like, you know, "knockoff." There are knockoff dresses that are sold by Macy's and Nordstrom.

We have to figure out what are the list of terms that really are pushing people to something that's almost unambiguously, to Mr. Abrams' point, infringing material. And we have started that process, and in fact we are in dialogue with the content community to ask them what are your key terms? What terms would you like us to include in that list, and how can we do that analysis and move forward?

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you. Let me follow up on that.

As I think you know, many members of the subcommittee are interested in your December 2 policy blog post regarding steps that Google would take to address the growing number of issues involving the use of its services in connection with copyright infringement.

Interesting among them was a pledge to, quote, "prevent terms that are closely associated with piracy from appearing in autocomplete. The Google feature, whereby Google's search engine will suggest search terms to its users as the users type, based on its prediction of what they might be looking for."

As you know, I am the co-chair of the bicameral Congressional International Anti-Piracy Caucus, along with Congressman Adam Schiff. Last year we released our annual international piracy watch list which included six foreign websites that are notorious for providing access to infringing copies of works by U.S. creators.

These included sites like The Pirate Bay, whose principals have been criminally convicted for their activities in Europe, and isoHunt, which is a file-sharing site that is the subject of an injunction issued by a U.S. court for copyright inducement and whose owner is described by another federal court as, quote, "an admitted copyright thief." I am told that a review of the 15 sites identified six weeks ago by the USTR as notorious markets for piracy show nearly identical results.

In other words, Google continues to suggest each one of those sites as search terms through the autocomplete function. I'd like to know what you're doing to address this problem, and if you're doing your best to prevent terms that are closely associated with piracy from appearing in autocomplete, again, obviously somebody looking for something, they can type out that whole word and won't get to it. But I think it would help Google's reputation as not aiding and abetting the infringement by not having these pop up on your autocomplete.

MR. WALKER: We understand the optics of it and we are working on it. I think it's an extension of our prior conversation.

The challenge is that a lot of those sites are Broadbase sites. The Chinese search engine Baidu, for example, I believe appears on that list. And Baidu does allow a large amount of pirated and infringing material to be accessible through its search engine, and yet we're in a difficult situation, essentially discriminating against this search competitor and bleeping him out of autocomplete.

So I think it's -- certainly the answer here would be the same as before, which is we really want to identify things that are unambiguously infringement and we are open to removing those from the autocomplete list.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you, Mr. Walker. I appreciate your answering those difficult questions. And to not single you entirely out, I have one for Ms. Jones.

You mentioned that Go Daddy strongly prefers DNS blocking by registrars, registries, to DNS filtering by ISPs as a strategy to shut down rogue websites because DNS filtering will not provide 100 percent protection. Is DSN blocking, as you describe it, effective against websites hosted and registered through overseas companies, and doesn't DNS filtering provide a better way to disable access to those types of foreign-based websites? Should both types of technologies be employed to combat the problem?

MS. JONES: To answer your last question first, yes, I think that is absolutely necessary and it's a pretty complicated technical explanation. I'll try not to get too much into the weeds.

But if you block DNS as the definitive root level, nobody can access the website from anywhere. The problem comes where you don't have cooperation from entities who are willing to do the blocking. And then you -- if you want to block at least some access, you may have to engage in some filtering. And we know that both blocking and filtering take place today in a variety of contexts.

The Internet community is a little bit remiss to employ these kind of tactics because the more you filter, the more you splinter, the less stable and secure the root becomes. And you end up with a giant grid of -- a three-dimensional grid, actually -- of things that are blocked by people, from people, in various geographies, and it gets -- it gets very shaky.

So really, that suggestion is more of a technical -- a technical approach, as opposed to a policy approach or a policy belief. But, you know, one of the -- (chuckles). Well, I was going to answer one of Mr. Walker's questions, but I know I'm not allowed to ask questions here, so I'll just leave it at that.

REP. GOODLATTE: That's good advice to yourself. (Laughter.)

And now -- now I'll recognize the gentleman from North Carolina, Mr. Watt.

REP. WATT: I can't resist. I've got to let her answer whatever question she wanted to answer. (Laughter.) if she's willing to answer it, I'm willing to listen to the answer.

MS. JONES: It just occurred to me that once in a while we have foreign websites that we can't block because they're -- (word inaudible) -- and we don't have a good cooperative U.S. company that's willing to do it. But so the example that the ICE gentleman put up here of the fake Louis Vuitton or the fake Nike, those are almost certainly -- I don't know. I haven't looked them up, but they're almost certainly at foreign registrars and foreign hosting providers, and they won't take them down.

But that -- no offense, Mr. Walker, but that doesn't mean that we can't disable the search to those. Because I can almost guarantee you that Louis Vuitton and Nike have contacted somebody to say, could you please stop sending people to those websites? It is an approach. And now he's going to have to --

MR. WALKER: And if I can --

REP. WATT: Well, what do you say to that, Mr. Walker?

MR. WALKER: Yeah. (Chuckles.) Thank you, sir. It's exactly right. I'm sure we are contacted by many of those sites and we remove them, and that's the way the system should work.

I mean, Louis Vuitton and Nike are in the best position to know what's appropriate and what's not. In many cases, when you put those search terms in, you may get ads for competitors, for example, and that's a good thing. Now you've -- competitive advertising, comparative advertising helps consumers. It helps them find out about more products that are out there, pay less money for them. If you're looking -- (inaudible).

(Cross talk.)

REP. WATT: What do you say to that, Ms. Jones?

MS. JONES: I happen to hear from the Louis Vuitton and Nike lawyers all day every day, and they're very, very willing to tell you which sites they want you to take down. So I don't have the data from any of the other providers, except for the ones that I represent, so I don't know if they have the list. But I would be shocked if they hadn't provided those.

REP. WATT: Mr. Morton, would it be more effective to block them or filter them?

MR. MORTON: Well, the -- as Ms. Jones noted, this gets very complicated, the sort of technical arrangements. What I'll say is first of all, on those sites, they weren't seized or terminated by industry. We seized them on both of those sites. We seized them and we forfeited both of those sites because they were notorious counterfeiting sites and they were referred to us by industry, and those are the instances in which you can have good cooperation between the government.

I think what you've heard going before suggests, however, that industry can do a lot more and on a much greater scale than government ever can be. We are part of the solution; we are not the solution, by a long shot.

REP. WATT: Mr. Abrams, any free speech implications in any of these -- and of those situations?

MR. ABRAMS: You know, everything we're talking about today is suffused with a danger of free speech violation. We don't want Google taking down sites just because people are angry at them or upset. We don't want the public to have less access unless we're talking about genuinely infringing or otherwise criminally or civilly violative sites.

It seems to me that the hard issue here is that we're often talking about taking down an infringing movie, say, taking down an infringing design, when the real problem is very often that these sites are only infringing sites. Everything on them is infringing.

And there the question is, as a congressional matter, what can you do about that? That's what the Senate focused on in its attempt to draft legislation. And I suggest to you that when you focus on drafting anything, that you ought to propose legislation which focuses not just on individual files, not an individual movie or an individual design only, but on the sites themselves which contain them. And --

REP. WATT: But wouldn't -- wouldn't a convenient way, quick way around that be just to put --

MR. ABRAMS: I'm sorry, I didn't hear the --

REP. WATT: Wouldn't a quick way around that be just to put up some legitimate -- put some legitimate stuff on the same site? I mean, seldom are you going to have a criminal that's not -- if you tell him that all you're doing is taking down sites that are exclusively dedicated to criminal activity, he's going to mix in a little -- a little legitimate stuff, don't you think?

MR. ABRAMS: Well, that's a fair point, and therefore what I'm talking about will never be a complete solution. But law enforcement authorities deal with that when they deal with, what, stores that sell, what, 90 percent of child pornography? They can close down the store in that circumstance.

If you get to a much lower amount, A, you've done something. You've accomplished something, I think, of a serious public policy nature. And then yes, you have to go after the individual sale of an individual book.

All I'm saying is that it is a step forward to try to deal with these sites, which is the reality, as I understand it, today where there are many sites which are either nothing but, or almost nothing but, infringing entities.

REP. WATT: I'm sure I have many more questions, Mr. Chairman, but out of respect to the other members, I'll come back around the next time, I guess.

REP. GOODLATTE: I thank the gentleman.

The gentleman from Arizona, Mr. Quayle, is recognized for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE BEN QUAYLE (R-AZ): Thank you -- thank you, Mr. Chairman, and thank you for holding this hearing.

Because annually billions of dollars are being stolen through pirated or counterfeit goods, and the last hearing that we had, a number of us, including myself, had mentioned some of our concern of how illegal streaming was being treated.

And I'm actually very pleased that the IP enforcement coordinated a victory. (Word inaudible) -- did a white paper recently which states that illegal streaming should be a felony and not a misdemeanor, as it currently is. And I know the chairman of this subcommittee and the full committee have been working on this, and I look forward to seeing a piece of legislation soon.

I'd also like to specifically thank Mr. Morton and ICE for all of their -- all their good work in enforcement against illegitimate sites, and I thank you for being here today.

But my first question is for you, Mr. Walker. Now, does Google currently have algorithms in place that allow ads that are paid for to show up during search results, based on the search terms that are placed into the query?

MR. WALKER: Yes. That's fundamentally how our -- what's called the ad word side of our business works.

REP. QUAYLE: And so those algorithms are basically personalized for each search result, based on the search terms that are utilized, correct?

MR. WALKER: They're personalized based on a lot of different factors. So for example -- in a different part of country, different time of day, different time of season, et cetera. But there's a correlation that takes a lot of things into account.

REP. QUAYLE: And are these updated regularly? Daily, weekly, monthly?

MR. WALKER: Almost instantaneously, because it looks at the quality of different websites, the amounts that different advertisers are paying, user preference. The more users click on an ad, the more popular it becomes and therefore more relevant. So a lot of factors that go into that. But it's almost in real time.

REP. QUAYLE: Look, I went to law school. I didn't -- wasn't an engineer, so that sounds --

MR. WALKER: Yeah, that makes -- that makes two of us. (Inaudible.)

REP. QUAYLE: That sounds pretty sophisticated. So based on that, I mean, Google has very extremely sophisticated algorithms that it uses in its search -- in its search results and queries. And because of that, Google has really become a noun and not just a verb. But based on that, you know, a recent report stated that domains classified as digital piracy attracted 32 million daily visits.

Do you think that a company that has sophisticated algorithms like Google could create an algorithm in which search requests using words that are among the most frequently associated with the crime are able to filter out those results? Have you ever -- have they tried to do this, or have you chosen not to?

MR. WALKER: Yeah, I -- the challenge is that it's sort of a different kettle of fish. The different (tasks ?) to solve. In the context of trying to come up with what's most relevant or related to a key word, taking all those different factors into account, you can use user feedback, as I referred to.

If lots of users, if you rank something fourth and all your users click on that, well, you probably made a mistake and it probably should be ranking higher, and vice versa. In the context of trying to target what's authorized and what's unauthorized on the web, that's a much harder challenge.

And the feedback loop we use there is essentially DMCA notices. We referred to before our process for when we get a notice of something from the rights holder, then we know it's illegal and we remove the link from our system. We don't just demote it; we take it out entirely.

REP. QUAYLE: Well, I remember an article in The New York Times -- I think it was earlier this year, regarding J.C. Penney and how it had been pushed to the top of the search results for everything from skinny jeans to grommeted-top curtains. Anything that you put into the search query in Google came up J.C. Penney.

Now, when you guys were actually notified of this, you changed your algorithm so that that wouldn't happen. How can you not then use that type of sophistication that you do -- I mean, I know you just explained that portion of it, but I think that it would seem to be feasible that those common search terms that are used to find pirated works on the Internet could be put into the algorithm so that those searches, then, the results are actually filtered out --

MR. WALKER: There are two problems there. I mean, one is that a lot of times searches, queries that are used to find pirated stuff are also used to find all sorts of other things as well. The word "cheap" or "discount" that I talked about before. So you're trying to separate the wheat from the chaff. That's problem one; you don't want to be over-inclusive and knock out a lot of legitimate sites.

REP. QUAYLE: Right.

MR. WALKER: Problem two is figuring out what the wheat is. And there we need to partner with the content industry, because there are lots of sites out there that make fair use of items, that have remixes and different sorts of things that are protected under the DMCA, again, that we don't want to knock out. So we rely on the content industry to say, you know, that's bad. That site is bad; pull that -- (inaudible).

You know, we don't want -- and I don't think the members of the committee want us or any company to be the judge, jury and executioner against an entire site.

REP. QUAYLE: No, I agree with that. But you've got to understand the frustration. I think Google does understand the frustration of those that have copyrighted work that's being infringed. Because recently just last week you reached a settlement, Google did, with six companies in which Google was suing because the companies were misusing Google's trademarks and name. in addition, I've read other pending lawsuits Google's involved in over domain names that are oddly similar to Google's domain name and logo.

In all of these instances, other companies were profiting off of Google. So I think I -- you can see where I'm going with this. I think you can understand the frustration of copyright holders, because they are having their content being illegally sold via the top results from searches on your search engine, and they are actually making a profit from that.

So can Google play a more proactive role in this, in combatting some of the deliberate, illegal sites and without infringing on any other parts of it?

MR. WALKER: Yeah, I think -- I think we can. And look, we not only understand the frustration, we share it. As you said, we're a big IP owner ourselves. We went after some bad guys who were misusing our name in scammy sort of ways that were misleading consumers. You know, "Buy the Google work-at-home kit," which of course had no association with Google, and pay 100 bucks to get a bunch of worthless paper. And we went after those guys and won that case.

And we're committed to doing that again for all these bad guys when we can identify them and clearly know who to go after. It's one thing for us, though, to be able to remove the individual links to stuff that we can look at and say, yeah, that's infringing, and another to try and go after the entire domain. That's a harder procedural thing for us as a private company to do.

REP. QUAYLE: Thank you very much.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank the gentleman.

The chair now recognizes the ranking member of the judiciary committee, the gentleman from Michigan, Mr. Conyers. And as I do that, I'll ask the vice chairman of the committee, Mr. Quayle, to take the chair.

REP. CONYERS: Thank you.

Attorney Christine Jones, why can't your organization build intellectual property protections into its user agreements and terminate customers that provide or facilitate online piracy?

MS. JONES: I'm sorry, I missed that last word. Online -- privacy?

REP. CONYERS: Piracy.

MS. JONES: Oh, piracy. I think we do substantially build those protections into our agreements, and the agreements are written generally very broadly. Like Google and other providers, we do rely on the content industry to let us know when they find things that are inappropriate.

But what we do that's somewhat more aggressive than most is if there is some infringing content and the person who runs the website doesn't cure it, we disable the entire website. Because you either are engaged in unlawful activity or you're not. There's no such thing as halfway. So if your domain name contains bad stuff and you don't take it down, we kill the entire domain. Period. If you fix it, we'll put it back up.

But we don't incentivize people to make part of their website good and part of their website bad, because as our First Amendment professor -- I'd call him a professor -- says, some it's good and some of it's bad and you have to be able to make a decision.

REP. CONYERS: You say you're doing it already?

MS. JONES: I think we do it already, yes, to the extent that we can.

REP. CONYERS: Mr. Kent Walker, when someone types in "child pornography" into a Google search, Google doesn't connect the user to images of child abuse. Now, that means to me that the technology exists to block illegal material from appearing in your searches.

Why don't you employ the same technology to block searches for illegal content and the illegal goods?

MR. WALKER: When it comes to child pornography, we do two things that are unique, compared to the problem of online counterfeiting and infringing material. Child pornography is recognizable to some degree with filters.

You can build a filter that'll detect flesh tones, for example. It knows flesh tones. The -- and that gives you a clue, and then you can use human reviewers to look at the sites one at a time. And to some degree, as the Supreme Court has put it, you know it when you see it. And we have people who are working on that.

In the context of unauthorized goods where it's not clear who's got the legal rights to something, it's much harder. You may remember the case that Viacom brought against YouTube not long ago. Viacom itself sued us over thousands of clips from their files that they had actually authorized -- they or their subsidiaries had authorized be uploaded to YouTube. So they themselves didn't actually know what was legitimate or what wasn't.

And that -- it's a harder problem.

REP. CONYERS: So why -- what's the -- why can't you block the searches? Tell me the answer again.

MR. WALKER: Sure. We can, in cooperation with the content owner. If they'd let us know that a given item is unauthorized, we -- we block that through. So we take that link out of our results, if it's for copyright infringement.

REP. CONYERS: Can I ask the director of ICE, I'm glad you didn't mention all the lack of due diligence and collateral damage that occurred February in your organization during recent seizures where legitimate sites were taken down in droves. Do you want to admit that before we get to the question?

MR. MORTON: Either way.

REP. CONYERS: What do you mean, either way?

MR. MORTON: If you want to continue the question --

REP. CONYERS: I mean, do you (admit ?) that that happened?

MR. MORTON: What happened in that case, Ranking Member Conyers, was this. That wasn't an IP investigation; it had to do with child pornography. We were investigating 10 sites that were offering images of children as young as four and five engaged in -- you know, in sexual --

REP. CONYERS: Yeah, but how did you get the good guys involved? Because that -- that's what I'm getting to.

MR. MORTON: What happened in that particular case was that in one of -- in one of the 10 sites that we were seizing, the seizure was overbroad and the site we were going after was a subdomain of a secondary domain level. And we seized for a little less than two days more than that site.

All the sites we -- two people contacted us. We noticed our error and we put all the sites back up.

REP. CONYERS: OK. Last question, with your forbearance, Mr. Chairman, to Professor Abrams.

What did you think of the Senate attempt on the same subject we're working on?

MR. ABRAMS: I thought the Senate attempt was constitutional. I think the notion of trying to define a rogue site in a way which requires, you know, a very stiff showing -- and a very difficult, but a possible showing of a site itself or the domain itself being so devoted --dedicated, in the draft statute's language -- to infringement works.

And I think that it works in a way which goes beyond the simple question of what can happen to that site. It deals -- it raises issues at least about intermediaries. I mean, if you have a court and the court says this whole site at this moment, as it is today, this whole site is an infringing site, and you get a court order to that effect and you serve it on ISPs, it seems to me perfectly constitutional to require the ISP not to carry material from the site.

And that would be true of other intermediaries as well, at least with respect to direct links to the site. I mean, I don't think you can limit information about the sites; I don't think -- I don't think Google can be limited any more than The Washington Post can be limited in writing about, containing a summary, describing, mentioning the website involved.

But I think intermediaries might well be able to be limited after being served with a finding by a court from linking to a site that has been held by a court to be an infringing one.

REP. QUAYLE: Thank you. The chair now recognizes the gentleman from North Carolina, Mr. Coble, for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE HOWARD COBLE (R-NC): Thank you, Mr. Chairman. It's good to have you all with us, I'll say to the panel.

Mr. Abrams, I think you touched on this. I was going to ask you how precise does the definition of rogue websites need to be in order to be constitutionally sound, but I think -- did you want to add anything to it? I think you've touched on that.

MR. ABRAMS: Not really. I mean, obviously language has to be very carefully drafted, but I think the notion, at least, of the Senate bill which focuses on dedicated-to-infringing with no other commercial purpose than infringing, which as I said, it's a very tough standard to meet. But if that can be met, I don't think there's a constitutional right of that site anymore to continue as it had been operating previously.

REP. COBLE: I thank you, sir.

Mr. Walker, some have alleged that Google benefits from illicit websites through advertising revenue. What do you say in response to that allegation?

MR. WALKER: These sites cost us money, sir. They cost us money to try and get rid of them; they cost us money when we find them and we refund money to advertisers. They cost us money when they use fake credit cards or stolen credit cards to pay for what they're doing. We have no interest in having advertising on these sites. We have no interest in having advertising leading to these sites.

There are two separate problems here. One is a problem of the digital piracy, songs and videos which typically are given away for free on the web. Those sites have no trouble drawing traffic. Everybody wants something for free. Those sites have a problem with modernization and so they use ad services to try and raise money, and we want to block that. And in fact, every time you see a Google ad on one of those sites, if they've gotten through our system, there's a way to click on that ad and report that site for having infringing content on.

There's a separate problem with regard to people selling counterfeit real goods, analog goods, traditional stuff. Those sites have no problem making money because they're (probably over there ?) making the good for this much and they're selling it for that good -- much. Their problem is they're trying to drive traffic. And so on that side, for our systems, that's an ad words problem.

And so we go through the ads on the Google sites and try to make sure that we don't have ads going to sites that are infringing, like the Louis Vuitton sites that we talked about before. And when we find it, when we hear about it, we pull them out.

REP. COBLE: I thank you, sir. Let me ask you another question, Mr. Walker. If Google learns that certain websites are illicit or illegal, can it restrict those websites from its searches?

MR. WALKER: So we've been talking this over on the advertising side. The search is more challenging and again, to Mr. Abrams' point, we -- need to be very focused here.

It is correct that if we have the government come and tell us that a given site is illegal, we can address that, that problem, in our search results. But we want to do that in a way that is -- obviously has appropriate due process involved and doesn't put us in the position of having to make those evaluations. Right now, we need to work together with the content industry to do that.

REP. COBLE: I thank you, sir.

Ms. Jones, what is your recommendation for the best approach to eliminate these websites in the United States and abroad? Or do you have a recommendation?

MS. JONES: Sure. I always have a recommendation. We -- (laughter) -- sorry. We have had a really good --

REP. COBLE: (Word inaudible) -- a good defense. If you can do it, it ain't braggin'. (Laughter.)

MS. JONES: (Laughs.) We've had a really -- we've had a really good string of luck with voluntary cooperation from all of the players on the Internet to take action against operators of websites that are engaged in bad actions, whatever their service is. So I recommend that we, as an industry, do that first and foremost.

So in other words, if I send to Google the 36,000 domain names that we took down under the Ryan Haight Act in 2010, I think Google ought to disable the search to those sites. And I think Visa and MasterCard and PayPal and Discover should disable the payment processing. And I think FedEx and UPS and the United States Postal Service should stop shipping drugs for those companies, and so and so forth.

However, we know that not everybody cooperates and not everybody's a good guy, so in addition to that, I think we have to have legislation that says if you don't, there's a consequence. If we give you notice and you take down your services, you're good. If we give you notice and you fail to respond, you're not good. That is my recommendation.

MR. MORTON: Mr. Coble, could I jump in that for just a moment?

REP. COBLE: Sure.

MR. MORTON: I want to make the point that the real way to go after these guys is to go after these guys and get them off the web. Because if they're out there, just saying they can't be in a search engine or they can't be in Facebook or they can't be on a blog or a link to them can't be there, isn't going to solve the problem. Because people are going to talk about them, and when they talk about the Pirate Bay or something else, those links are going to come back up in any search engine worth its salt.

So our worry is that we can cut off -- we'd recommend cutting off the money to these guys, cut off the advertising, cut off the financial services. When you start to go after the pure search side of it, the risk is that you're both overbroad and ultimately ineffective in doing it.

REP. COBLE: I see my red light has illuminated. I yield back. Good to have you all with us this morning. Thank you.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you. The chair now recognizes the gentlewoman from California, Ms. Lofgren, for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE ZOE LOFGREN (D-CA): Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

I think this is an excellent hearing and it shows how complicated some of these issues are. And yet it is important that we deal with the challenges in a way that is serious but also works as a technical matter and also with an eye to our Constitution, not only the First Amendment, but the Fourth Amendment. We want to make sure that we're effective but smart.

And along those lines, Mr. Morton, I was interested in -- the Operation In Our Sites effort, how many of the owners of those sites that were the subject of your actions, how many of those owners were arrested? And for the seizures that have not been followed by an arrest, has ICE attempted to make arrests and if not, why not?

MR. MORTON: I'll have to get you the exact numbers, Ms. Lofgren. But the -- a couple of things are going on. There -- several of these cases are part of an ongoing criminal investigation, so I can't really predict one way or another how they're going to end up. A few people have arrest -- been arrested, and I can get you those stats.

But the real challenge, as I alluded to in the beginning, is that in many of these cases, we have a criminal investigation but most of the actors are, for practical purposes, outside of our reach. They're not in this country. They're in --

REP. LOFGREN: Well, perhaps what I can do off-calendar is just get the stats. Because I -- you're bringing-- you're going to court, you're bringing a criminal action, you're getting a matter signed by a magistrate, and I want to know then what? How many criminal prosecutions? How many arrests?

And I'm eager -- I understand that somebody is not as -- outside our jurisdiction, that's a more complicated factor, which goes to the other question I have, which has to do with the jurisdiction itself.

Now, my understanding is that the customs part of ICE, they have jurisdiction over goods that cross international borders. What is the limit on ICE's authority over the Internet? Is it the international aspect of it, or is it ICE's position that you have jurisdiction over the Internet itself?

MR. MORTON: That is -- that latter proposition is not our position. Our position is that we have jurisdiction over the relevant federal offenses, provided there is the necessary constitutional nexus to the United States for the Congress to assert jurisdiction.

So in practical terms, that means there needs to be some element or instrument of the crime occurring here in the United States.

REP. LOFGREN: So the -- it's wrongdoing crossing into the United States, is that -- involving --

MR. MORTON: That's right. Involving the United States or United States right holder, some U.S. interest.

REP. LOFGREN: But there has to be an international component.

MR. MORTON: That's right. If you were engaged in counterfeiting of Indian goods in China and there was no nexus whatsoever to the United States at all, that's not a case we would investigate --

REP. LOFGREN: All right. Let me ask you this, and it's something that I think people -- obviously we have a need for enforcement, but we also -- and want to make sure that things were done in a proper way. And recently -- and I don't mean to say, obviously we're not the same -- but Russia used copyright enforcement -- it was -- it was pirated copies of Microsoft software.

They used those pirated copies as an excuse to go in and take computers and shut down dissident groups -- and there was in fact infringement going on, but they used it really for political reasons. What do we have in place that would prevent the government from that sort of activity here?

MR. MORTON: Well, I'm not familiar with that particular case, but I think the short answer to your question is that we have a wonderful judicial system in this country. We have a great sense of the rule of law. We have a great sense of ethical behavior on the part of government. I have to go to --

REP. LOFGREN: No, but -- but -- no, but procedurally. Right now there's -- there's an ex parte communication. You go to a magistrate. You say what you think. There's nobody on the other side saying what they think. You get, in most cases, the order, you take it down.

What's -- what's the -- (inaudible) -- on you?

MR. MORTON: Well, I have to demonstrate that there is probable cause for the seizure to the federal judge, and the day we do it, you can walk into court and challenge that seizure immediately. And in addition to the separate rights you have to challenge the ultimate forfeiture, if the government pursues a permanent seizure of the site. So there's a tremendous amount of process that is provided for -- upon seizure.

The seizure itself follows the traditional rules in Rule 41 where we go to a -- a judge, ex parte, and we say we believe a crime is being committed.

REP. LOFGREN: I have about five pages more of questions for you, so Mr. Morton, I will deliver those to you in writing.

And I wonder, as I listened, especially to the testimony from Go Daddy and Google, I'm reminded that this stuff is more complicated than is -- than is obviously understood, and how useful it might be to have some of the big tech presences engage in more deep conversations with content holders who are understandably concerned about what's happening to them. And that -- that might yield a -- an effective result that is far superior to what the non-engineers in the Congress might craft.

So I would just leave that suggestion with the panel. They don't need the permission of the Congress to do that, but I think that might be a good outcome of this hearing.

And I yield back the balance of my time.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you.

The chair now recognizes the gentleman from California, Mr. Issa, for five minutes.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R-CA): I thank the chairman.

I think I'll take the liberty of taking us a little off IP for a moment, since we have the representative of ICE here. What's the financial threshold for you to care about counterfeiting?

MR. MORTON: Typically there isn't one. We're quite aggressive when it comes to intellectual property enforcement. Obviously the various prosecutors, the United States attorneys' offices we deal with do have at some point some limitations. There's enough work out there--

REP. ISSA: Why don't -- why don't you -- yeah, why don't you give us an idea? You know, there was a movie back, I think, in the '30s with Cagney, "Never Steal Anything Small." And it was actually a union organization, but it was -- it was a great one because basically he stole enough to be hero of the union.

When -- how do we change the system, which Congress has the right to do, so that every single crime that you know is a crime can in fact be pursued in a way that will allow a change of behavior? Now, I'm not talking about going after the P2P swapper who is changing his own library with somebody down the street.

But I'm talking about somebody who commercializes the selling of counterfeits. And I did not say intellectual property; I said counterfeits. I don't see a difference; I don't think anyone on this panel should see a difference of whether it is tangible and you can feel and touch it or it simply plays through a speaker.

What would change -- what change in the law would allow you to pursue everyone, for all practical purposes, where today you probably pursue what, one-half, one-quarter, one-tenth of 1 percent? Certainly you pursue less than 1 percent in the tangible world, don't you?

If you find -- and I'll get to the question -- if you find -- and I'll take an example from my own life. You find 500 Viper alarms inside a shipment of -- my former life, if you will -- inside a shipment of clothing. And it's designated as clothing, and you find it, basically you seize it and that's the end of the story, isn't it?

So you found tens of thousands of dollars of value. You found registered trademarks, copies of the images that make the product real, patented product, tangible, and the most you'll do is destroy it. That is the practical reality today, whether -- and you're shaking your head yes.

That's the record that I hope we'll make here today, is that we're talking about -- and I appreciate all the people in the IP world. We're talking about organizations, we're saying you have to do better. You have to get it down to zero.

What can we do, in your opinion -- and I'll take from each of you, please -- to get to a zero tolerance? And I'm not trying to get you to go after fake Viper car alarms or Polk audio or any of the other things from my own past. But I'll give you a recent one, and I'll give it to you as an anecdotal.

About a year ago my congressional office ordered a USB thumb drive. They were tired of me carrying three different thumb drives, so we ordered one of the new 256-gig thumb drives. We ordered it from one of the major companies not represented here today. Their vendor was a group which I will give, called Fantastic Deal. Now, today they're called Good Old Deal and Fantastic Deal. But if you Google them -- and you will get the actual company selling on that other company.

So the metadata that they put in to make sure that they still come up under their old name of Fantastic Deal -- and by the way, they're still Fantastic Deal when they tell you that we at Fantastic Deal are committed to your satisfaction; please don't hesitate to contact us. They flat-shipped a, on its face -- it was 256 gig, but it was not made by Kingston; it was not authentic in any way, shape or form, and they shipped it out. It is still selling. They paid no price for it. The most they had to do was live up to that company's guarantee of letting me cancel the credit card, which I did around them anyway.

What change from the dais here will allow you to not let those go, because they didn't meet a financial threshold that was in the tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars?

MR. MORTON: Let me start, and then -- I'll try to be brief so the rest of the panel can give you're their thoughts as well.

If -- there -- some of it's a resource issue. Some of it is -- take ICE, for example, a question of balancing competing enforcement priorities. Obviously we're going to have to go after the cartel members and child pornographers and other things of weighty importance to the nation.

I think the big challenges are focusing on the foreign actors who are in the game for the -- you know, as a form of organized crime and have no intention whatsoever of coming to the United States, of basing their operations here. They are able, sadly in many instances, through the Internet to commit a crime on the United States on a grand scale, on a repeated scale, from afar.

And so we need, I think, a balance of authorities. Criminal authorities will never get us all there --civil authorities address that; aggressive seizure, penalties for where we can bring U.S. enforcement action. International cooperation is critical.

You could give ICE triple the number of agents it has. We have no authority to arrest people in China. We have no authority to -- (inaudible).

(Cross talk.)

REP. ISSA: I appreciate that, although all the examples I gave had a U.S. nexus. Could you -- the rest of you weigh in, please?

MR. ABRAMS: I agree with Mr. Morton. I think all we can do, but it's important, is to do everything we can to drain actions of this sort of the profits that have been building up over the years and increasing, indeed, more and more as time passes. Because I agree that the criminal law is not going to work very easily or comfortably when you deal with foreign actors that never come here.

So we're going to have to work, I think in the main, through changes in our civil legislation to take all the steps that we can to make it impossible or at least very difficult for these entities to continue to engage in the criminal -- and it is criminal -- activity that they're currently engaged in.

REP. ISSA: Mr. Walker?

MR. WALKER: I'd have three thoughts, building on the comments here. First, go after the bad guys directly, whether that's more resources for ICE or otherwise. Second, it is an international problem. Right now, the MLAP process, that Multilateral Legal Assistance Treaty process, is broken. It can take months, sometimes up to six months, for an international law enforcement to cooperate with each other in going after these guys. That doesn't work for them and it doesn't work for us in trying to stop it.

And then lastly, I agree again, follow the money. If we can cut off the funding sources and identify the bad guys and then cut off advertising on their sites, that'll be powerful.

REP. ISSA: Ms. Jones?

MS. JONES: Thank you, sir. I would second the comments of my panel -- fellow panel members, but also from the dais, what you can do to be helpful to us, to answer your question, is give us cover so that if we take action against these people, we have a safe harbor. We don't have people suing us, we're not going to jail. We want to help you, but you have to help us help you.

REP. ISSA: Thank you for the best of all answers.

I yield back.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you. I just want to -- (word inaudible) -- as we have been called for a vote, but the chair recognizes the gentlelady from California, Ms. Chu, for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE JUDY CHU (D-CA): Well, thank you, Mr. Chair, for convening this important hearing. And as you know, this issue of online piracy is of great concern to my Los Angeles district, given the importance of the motion picture and recording industry to the city and the many residents who are employed by them. So I hope that we can all work together to come up with a solution that gives law enforcement a real tool to stop this practice.

And while the Combatting Online Infringement and Counterfeits Act that was introduced in the Senate last year is a great start, I am concerned that it doesn't address the problem of cyber lockers that are flooded with infringing content.

It's important that we don't hurt legitimate business interests, but these businesses that reward these customers for uploading infringing content and refuse to penalize the offenders are not legitimate business interests. So I hope that we can address these infringing websites and cyber lockers.

I also want to thank Mr. Morton for joining us today and for all the great work that he's done on the Operation In Our Sites.

And let me just start then by asking Mr. Walker, I am very concerned of course, as you heard about the infringement facilitated by the cyber lockers, but I don't want to affect legitimate developments in cloud computing.

How can Congress help law enforcement go after the bad actors in the cyber locker space without inferring with -- interfering with legitimate economic interests?

MR. WALKER: It's the right balance to draw, Congresswoman. The challenge with cyber lockers, which are really just a different way of describing storing content online, is a real one. Because as you can tell, the entire direction of the industry is in favor of moving toward the cloud, allowing people across the country, across the world, to access music, video, content, documents, email in much more flexible ways that they were able to even a dozen years ago.

That's a great thing for consumers and then, we think, ultimately a great thing for the content industries and -- if it provides more platforms and more ways that people can consume content, lawfully and legitimately. iTunes is, in a sense, a version of the cyber locker that allows you to download information from the cloud. We've seen other significant companies launch ways of offering online storage.

When you get into the question of the legitimacy of the business or not, it really goes to the question of an intent to induce an infringement. And the existing copyright laws have been used in some cases to go after companies that clearly, again, are sort of dedicated to just having illegal content ousted and promoting that kind of activity, distinguished from legitimate companies who may have broadbase multipurpose storage that is abused by some of their users. That does raise more difficult -- (inaudible) -- the question.

REP. CHU: How about you, Ms. Jones? I understand that Go Daddy also provides remote storage services. How can we ensure that law enforcement has all the tools that it needs to go after cyber lockers that intentionally promote the sharing of infringing content, without impeding legitimate businesses?

MS. JONES: We are a very large provider of cloud-based services, and it's difficult for us to go, say, scan all of the files that are stored on our online file folder products. But what we can do is limit storage, limit bandwidth usage and know patterns of behavior so that if there are very, very, very large quantities of data and they all seem to be copies of movies, our system might pick that kind of thing up.

But short of that, it's really important to us to have information from the content providers so if it's the song makers, the movie makers, the video producers, whatever those people are, to help us be helpful. And also so that it helps law enforcement to know which ones to go after, because it's not enough for me to just say customer A has 47 dedicated servers and they're all filled with video stuff, it's not good enough. Because I don't know if it's legitimate content or not. That guy could have bought 47 dedicated servers' worth of videos.

So it's really important for us to be able to identify -- and I think Mr. Walker has pointed this out as well -- what is legitimate content and what's not, so that we can -- again, we don't want to be facilitating bad guys, but we need -- we need help to identify which ones they are.

REP. CHU: Thank you. And Mr. Morton, what are the next steps in Operation In Our Sites?

MR. MORTON: Well, we're going to continue to work with industry. We've been very careful not to focus on any one industry over the other. As you know, sadly, the whole landscape of American industry is under assault right now, so we'll focus on pharmaceutical sites, we'll focus on entertainment sites. In -- the counterfeiting sites we can do all day long, sadly, there are so many of them.

And we're just going to keep at it. Wherever we can we're going to pursue a full criminal investigation for those sites where all of the elements of the crime other than the domain name are outside of the United States, we'll focus on the domain names and take them down as aggressively as we can, recognizing we are -- that's not the long- term solution. It's one part of trying to combat this problem.

But we've got to do something. My perspective is do nothing, and you fail. And so we've tried very hard to get out there to do something and work with the other parts of the system to get us to a better, more comprehensive solution.

REP. LOFGREN: Thank you. I yield back.

REP. GOODLATTE: Thank you very much. As previously noted, we have a vote, so this hearing shall be temporarily adjourned until immediately following the vote.

REP. WATT: Recessed.

REP. GOODLATTE: Recessed. Thank you, Mr. Watt. (Laughter.)

(Recess.)

REP. GOODLATTE: The committee will reconvene. And before I turn to the gentleman from California, I would like to ask unanimous consent to enter in the record two letters, one from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children dated March 30, 2011, addressed to Chairman Smith and pertinent to the issue raised by the gentlewoman from California. And another, a letter to the members of the United States Congress from a coalition of groups dated March 30, 2011, and on a related subject.

And at this time it's my pleasure to recognize the gentleman from California, Mr. Berman, for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE HOWARD BERMAN (D-CA): Well, thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. And thank all of you for your testimony. And Mr. Morton, I want to join with others in raising I think some very effective initiatives you're undertaking to deal with the problem we're discussing today.

Mr. Walker, I appreciate your testimony and your comments about the Digital Millennium Copyright. I'm sure the chairman of the subcommittee does. He's spent a great deal of time negotiating that legislation, and a lot of us were involved in it.

But if -- if that legislation were really working, I don't think we'd be having this hearing. I don't think there'd be a Senate bill. I don't think customs would be undertaking the initiatives it is undertaking.

Ms. Lofgren is right. This is a complicated subject, but there's one element that's quite simple, and that is that truly billions of dollars and thousands of jobs are being lost because of digital theft. And I think we're focused on trying to do something about it.

But I wanted to take off on -- in terms of a legislative approach, I wanted to take off on what you said. You said that Google doesn't want to be the judge, jury and executioner. But right now, under the Digital Millennium Copyright, you are the judge, jury and executioner. You don't just take down anything that you're asked to take down; you go and try and go through some process to determine if it's a valid request, if in fact it's directed at infringing material.

The legislative approach is an approach, (truncated ?) process where a judge is the judge and all you have to do is be the executioner. And I'm wondering if, in that sense, it doesn't -- this might be something you'd be more enthusiastic about because it puts the onus of looking at the whole site and whether it is -- I mean, nothing's going to be 100 percent infringing, because some things will be in the public domain that could be on that site. But fundamentally, it is a site that is marketing illegally placed content -- content without permission of the copyright owner.

There was -- so I guess I would like your thoughts -- I'll ask a few questions and you could answer them. One is I would like your thoughts on whether having a judge rule that a site itself is dedicated to infringement and blocking that site may be a far more effective way of assuring due process while actually making a difference.

And also your reaction to the notion that the DMCA, as good as it is, in the context of today's technology, yeah, you get that takedown letter. You try to do it expeditiously, although there is testimony submitted for the record which say it frequently takes as much as 24 -- 20 days for you -- or maybe that's an average of time before it actually, the link comes down. And I believe Google has said they're going to try and do this within 24 hours.

But I do notice that the searches and the algorithms take a few seconds, so -- and when you're talking about a newly released film or music, 24 hours on a site is disaster in terms of millions of people who can then get it for free. But your notion of why this -- a judge doing this isn't more effective than putting all the onus on you.

And correct me if I'm wrong, but when you get such a letter, you take down the link to that site. I don't even know if you have the legal ability or the -- not the functional ability to take down that site as a site. So all you're doing is taking out a link to one of what could be thousands of different works that are on that site. It is -- it's a little bit like trying to empty the ocean with a bucket, and I'd like to get your reaction to some of those things.

MR. WALKER: Sure. There were a lot of comments there, so let me try and address them all and if I miss one, please let me know.

I would say our fundamental position is that we agree that there's a way to complement the DMCA. The DMCA has been very effective for what it's done, but there are ways, additional measures that can be taken to go after the money, to go after some of the advertising, to after the payment processors that may reach some things that are outside the copyright domain -- counterfeiting and the like. And we've indicated we're happy to work with the subcommittee on that.

It is -- there is a balance, obviously, because there are millions of dollars, billions of dollars, on each side of the table. I mean, Google's accounts were $54 billion in economic activity in the United States --

REP. BERMAN: Yeah, but that's -- that -- you know, but I mean that's important, and innovation is important. But to the extent that some portion of that billions of dollars is coming from giving people access to copyrighted works that they didn't have their permission to use, it's the fruits of poisonous trees.

MR. WALKER: Sure. We understand that and we don't want money from illegal purposes, from illegal services, and never have. But, you know, most of it, the vast majority, is going to small businesses, small publishers, advertisers whose businesses actually exist because the Internet is out there.

REP. BERMAN: Sure.

MR. WALKER: So we're trying to, again, separate the wheat from the chaff and do it in the most effective way we can. The DMCA has been a good model for what it's done. That notice and takedown has been very robust and it's been adopted -- the work of this committee and Congress -- has been adopted around the world, in Europe and elsewhere. So we want to be careful about doing something that would undercut that. But that's not to say we're opposed to additional sort of targeted measures that go after things.

To your comments and Ms. Lofgren's comments earlier, we are in fairly frequent conversations with the general counsels and representatives of the trade associations of the major motion picture studios, the RIAA, et cetera, to try and refine and improve and streamline our processes.

It's -- in many cases, it is challenging. It does take a long time, and we're hoping to make it a much shorter time, to go back and forth through the different DMCA notices we get. There are a lot of people out there who don't understand copyright law or are using them for abusive purposes to try and take down competitor sites without a legitimate legal claim, and we need to sort through those.

But I think we can do it, especially with regard to some of the online tools that we're soon to be launching, in a much faster way than we're doing now.

You had asked also with regard to the question of -- there's one question about pre-release movies. We've actually talked to the studios about that and are there ways of being able to address that in an even more expedited fashion, where there's real economic injury being -- at issue there.

And then lastly I would say we do have -- focusing in on your question with regard to whether or not a court finding would be useful in this. Before we, you know, before anyone takes significant steps of taking away a domain name or cutting off advertising to a site, I think it is appropriate for a court to weigh in with appropriate due process to review that.

And the model of doing that in a way that's targeted on the truly bad sites -- and I think, you know, for some reasons we've talked with the staff on the Senate side with regard to the bill that was introduced in the last session, in some ways that definition was somewhat overbroad and created some of the free expression and due process issues we've talked about.

But we're optimistic that we can work together to get to a more focused definition. And we would be prepared to support that.

REP. BERMAN: Mr. Chairman, I know my time is quite expired. It's just -- could I squeeze one more in here, though?

REP. GOODLATTE: Without objection.

REP. BERMAN: In your testimony you say the DMCA has practical and real effect in thwarting infringement. Legislation that targets the worst of the worst should not increase liability for online services that are playing by the rules.

What if we maintained the level of liability, not increase the liability, but required more affirmative steps be undertaken under that standard of liability?

MR. WALKER: Well, I think much of that proposal, again, on the Senate side, would have required affirmative steps, based on a finding that a given site was dedicated to illegal content. By having us remove it from our search results, and we are willing --

REP. BERMAN: But that doesn't increase your liability. That -- the --

MR. WALKER: No, this would affect -- I think generally not. Ms. Jones has raised concerns about, you know, needing to have a safe harbor on that side. But generally speaking, we've been able to terminate people for violating our policies without getting suits back from the bad guys in response.

Our focus has been mostly on the collateral consequences of undermining the DMCA. For example, if a site is adjudged to be bad and that URL is out there, and then somebody using our services posts it, posts that URL in a Google doc or in an email -- I send you an email; it includes that URL. Well, Google is now posting that content, in a sense. Are we liable for including that URL? I think the common-sense answer is no, we shouldn't be, and that the DMCA insulates that from liability.

But if just that sort of in rem order would deem to be de facto red-flag knowledge, there'd at least be an open question. So we need to clarify those kinds of unintended consequences.

REP. BERMAN: (Off mic.)

REP. GOODLATTE: The gentleman from Florida, Mr. Deutch, is recognized for five minutes.

REPRESENTATIVE TED DEUTCH (D-FL): Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
